question: While working as the medical resident on call, you are paged to see a 72-year-old woman who complains of a headache. Upon seeing you, she snaps, "You look young and foolish. | hope you're more efficient than you seem." While you are performing a basic physical examination an her, she says, "I'm going ta complain ta the hospital administrators about you because you have no idea how to properly deal with a patient." Which of the following is the best response to her threat?
options: A "Feel free to do as you please.”
B. "Please allow me to complete the physical examination first."
C. "You seem to be angry, and | don't know why "
D. "You're hurting me with your comments."

question: A 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department in an agitated state, certain that she is "about to die" Fifteen minutes ago, she developed heart palpitations and a severe "viselike" tightness in her chest. She experienced a similar episode last week, which resolved in twenty minutes. She denies using any drugs and her medical history is unremarkable. Her father has a histary of heart disease and her mother has diabetes mellitus. She takes no medications. Vital signs are temperature 37.0°C (98 6°F), blood pressure 132/74 mmHg, pulse 118/min, and respiratory rate 30/min. She is sweating profusely. EKG reveals sinus tachycardia. The most appropriate next step is administration of which of the following?

As the on-call surgery resident, you are paged to see a patient on the ward wha is having seizures. The patient is a 35-year-old male who underwent a cholecystectomy yesterday. His surgery was uneventful and the man appeared to be doing well until an hour ago when he developed altered sensaorium. Upan arriving on the floor, you discover the patient to be confused and agitated. His vital signs include a temperature of 38C (100 4F), blood pressure of 134/86 mm Hg, pulse of 110/min, and respirations of 18/min. The man is diaphoretic and has tremars. His wound incisions show no evidence of inflammation, and biliary drainage appears adequate. A review of his medical record indicates his medical history to be unremarkable except for mild esophagitis. He smokes a pack of cigarettes per day and drinks 6-10 beers per night. His medications include folic acid, thiamine, and omeprazole. Laboratory results include the following:
CBC
Hb                       14 1g/dL

Serum Chemistry
Sodium                 137 mEq/L
Potassium             4 0 mEg/L
Chlaride            101 mEgiL

Creatinine              1.0 mg/dL

Arterial Blood Gas
FH             740
PO2                    94 mm Hg

Which of the following should be initiated immediately in this patient?

A 35-year-old Caucasian male with a chronic history of paranoid schizophrenia presents to the mental health clinic. He strongly believes that his wife recently stole his pill bottle of risperidone, which he feels caused him to start experiencing mare frequent and intense auditory hallucinations. He says that the "voices" tell him to Kill his wife because she cannot be trusted. He admits to having homicidal thoughts about his wife but denies any specific plan for harming her. options: A. Refill his prescription of risperidone and call his wife after he leaves
B. Refill his prescription of risperidone without calling his wife as he does not have a plan to hurt her
C. Admit the patient to the psychiatric ward
D. Call the patient's wife immediately before filling the risperidone prescription

question: A 34-year-old woman who describes herself as a "holistic healer" brings her two children aged four years and three years ta the pediatrician for routine physical examinations. This is a first visit as they have recently moved from another state. The medical recards for the children indicate that no immunizations have been given. When the mother is questioned about this, she proudly replies, "My children are wonderfully healthy on their own and have no need for these artificial vaccines." The principles and benefits of immunization are discussed at length, as well as the risks inherent in not being immunized. The physician recommends that the children be given all age-appropriate vaccinations today. The mother remains convinced that immunizations cause mare harm than good, and she steadfastly refuses to allow her children to be vaccinated. What is the most appropriate next step?
options: A. Obtain a court order for immunization of children
C. Inform mother that she will be reported to the local health department
D. Document in the medical chart that the risks and benefits of vaccination have been explained

question: A 48-year-old woman notices a firm, fixed mass in her right breast but chooses to ignore it. The mass is then detected on her annual physical examination eight months later. By that point, the mass has increased greatly in size. When questioned as ta why she did not report the mass when she first noticed it, the woman states that she was not concerned about the mass because she does nat have a family history of breast cancer. This response is an example of which of the following defense mechanisms?

A B0-year-old physician is admitted to the hospital for jaundice and weight loss. He denies other symptoms, including abdominal pain and alterations in bowel movements. His past medical history is noncontributory. He denies any histary of significant alcahal intake but admits to a 30-pack-year smoking histary. A detailed work-up eventually reveals the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma. Shortly after his discharge, he spends several hours per day on his laptop computer so that he can obtain the latest information an his illness. Which of the following psychalogical defense mechanisms is this physician most likely employing?

A 37-year-old obese man returns to his doctor for a follow-up visit. One manth ago, he was diagnosed with type Il diabetes mellitus and was started on metformin. His fasting glucose is 122 mg/dL, and his blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. The patient looks rather dejected and admits it has been difficult to come to terms with his diagnosis. He has tried to exercise, watch his diet, and quit smoking as was suggested, but lately he has been feeling unmotivated and without energy. He admits ta feeling sad and guilty about his weight, but is not sure he will be able to do anything about it. He continues to smoke despite attempts to cut back, and has been spending much of the day in bed watching television or sleeping. He has withdrawn from friends and family and took the last twa weeks off from work, as he did not feel "up to going." Which of the following would be the best medication to prescribe at this ime?

A 27-year-old male presents to clinic complaining of "marital problems " He says that far the past year that he has been married, he and his wife have not successfully had sexual intercourse on even one occasion. He strongly feels that she either finds him physically unattractive ar is having an affair with another man. He adds that he is extremely frustrated with his wife "contracting herself" which prevents any kind of vaginal penetration. After several failed attempts, his wife now avoids any sexual intimacy with him. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 19-year-old student is referred to the university health center far inability to complete his assignments. He has always been a good student, and was valedictorian of his high school class. However, since starting college, he has found it difficult to keep up with all the wark. He audio-recards every class, playing the tapes back later in the day to transcribe each entire lecture word for word. He admits to sometimes needing to go aver certain sections multiple times to be sure he has heard correctly. He also takes a long time to complete assignments, as he always checks his work multiple times prior to handing it in. Because of this, he has had to ask for many extensions an his assignments. He is sure to complete all his assignments, even after they have been reviewed in class and even though they are not graded. He spends all his time doing his classwaork, and is not involved in social activities. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 46-year-old man with a history of medication-controlled hypertension sees his doctor for a routine check-up. His blood pressure is 115/80 mm Hg and an electracardiogram shows a normal sinus rhythm. The doctor notes that the man seems more down than usual. The man admits that he has been "stressed out" for the past two weeks, as a few peaple at work recently quit and he has had to take on more work while management finds replacements. He has been sleeping poorly at night, feels tired during the day, and states that he hates his job right now, but has no ather choice. He continues to get his wark done and enjoys social activities, remarking that he "can still golf an the weekends." What is the patient's most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood

question: A colleague who works as a pediatrician in your group practice comes to your office to inquire about a patient you examined earlier this morning. The colleague says that he recognized the patient as a former neighbor of his who is also a good friend af the family. The patient was recently diagnosed as HIV-positive and is naw an antiretroviral medication. Your colleague asks what the patient is being treated for. What is the most appropriate response to such an inquiry?
options: A. "He is on antiretrovirals because he is HIV positive."
B. "Actually, we've not been able to diagnose his condition."
C."Itis unprofessional of you to ask me this question.”
D."l don't think it would be appropriate for me to discuss this with you."

question: A 54-year-old male with a history of chronic alcoholism is admitted to the hospital with hematemesis and abdominal distension. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals the presence of esophageal varices. Continued warkup of his condition results in a diagnosis of cirrhosis of the liver. He is treated appropriately and strongly counseled about the need to abstain from alcohol. He is then discharged home. After discharge, he begins to work as a full-time volunteer for a non-profit organization that assists patients with alcoholic cirrhosis. Which of the following defense mechanisms is this man using?

A 28-year-old attorney presents complaining of a six-month history of extreme nervousness, irmtability, and restlessness. He is "plagued" by recurrent thoughts of not being able to properly carry out his responsibilities at the office. He dreads the possibility of not being offered a position as partner in the law firm. As a result, he finds himself unable to concentrate well or perform his duties efficiently. He is also engaged to be married, and spends sleepless nights thinking about the responsibilities of married life. He worries that he will not be a good husband or father. He denies any history of alcohol intake, but has recently begun drinking two bottles of beer every night for the past month as a means of escaping from his distressing thoughts. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this patient?
options: A. Propanolol before a distressing situation

question: A 16-year-old female presents to her pediatrician's office for a routine examination. She is wearing a sweater despite the warm weather, and admits she often feels cold. She states that she has otherwise been feeling fine, except for having difficulty losing weight. She wants ta lose about 10 lbs (4.5 kg) because she believes she is "too fat." She has been on a strict diet and exercises two hours daily. She is also requesting a pregnancy test because she has not had a menstrual period for the past three months. Past medical history is significant far a supracondylar fracture of her right humerus at the age of seven. She is alert, cooperative, and in no apparent distress. Vital signs are temperature 36.2°C (97.2°F), blood pressure 88/58 mmHg, pulse 56/min, and respiratory rate 16/min. Her height is 5'5" {165 cm) and weight is 90 lbs (40.9 kg). What is the mast appropriate next step in the management of her symptoms?
options: A Advise the patient that her complaints likely stem from a thyroid disorder.
B. Advise the patient that she is underweight and needs to increase her caloric intake.
C. Refer the patient for cognitive-behavioral therapy to address her weight.
D. Recommend the patient to begin taking sertraline.

question: A 21-year-old male is admitted to the intensive care unit after attempting to commit suicide by overdosing on some pills he found in the medicine cabinet at home. A psychiatry consult is ordered. While interviewing the patient, the psychiatrist observes that the patient has a "blank" expression on his face and is minimally responsive. He refuses to make eye contact and speaks in monosyllables. An attempt is made to obtain a more detailed history from the patient's father. He describes his son as very aloof, having avoided the other children in the neighborhood and participated in few activities as a child. His son dropped out of school in ninth grade and has not been able to maintain jobs throughout the years because of his social difficulties. He adds that his son has been increasingly isolated this past year and that he has complained his deceased maother frequently asks him ta "join her in heaven." Which of the following medications would provide the greatest benefit to this patient?

A 26-year-old graduate student presents at her husband's urging, complaining of severe pain during sexual intercourse. She says that she was a virgin when she married her husband two years ago, and that she has been experiencing severe "genital pain" during sex since then. As a result, she avoids sexual intimacy with her husband, which is placing a strain upan their marriage. She also complains of intense pain with her menses and when passing stool. She admits to sporadic pelvic pain that waxes and wanes with no discernible trigger. What would be the most appropriate treatment given this woman's condition?

A 28-year-old male presents for a follow-up visit regarding his bipolar disorder, which has been managed with valproic acid for several years. He is accompanied by his mother who is very concerned because her son has been behaving strangely for the past two weeks, saying that he can hear the voice of his long-deceased father telling him to "came to me." The patient insists that he is able to ignore his father's vaice and that he is nat considering suicide at this time. The decision is made to start risperidone to treat the auditory hallucinations. This medication predominantly produces its antipsychotic effect by blocking which of the following receptors?

A 52-year-old Caucasian male presents complaining of diminished energy far the past three months. He appears very sad and moves slowly. He says that he has been feeling terrible after his wife died in a car accident three manths ago. He is filled with thoughts of quilt because he was driving the car when the accident took place. Since then, he has been suffering from disturbed sleep and finds himself unable to focus an his favorite activities, like coin collecting or fishing. He reparts being disturbed by repeated flashbacks of the event. He keeps himself aloof and isolated from others because he "just doesn't feel like socializing anymore." He adds that he has a poor appetite and has gained 20 lbs (9.1 kg). He admits to wanting to "end my life in arder to escape the memories af that nightmarish day." He Is able to contract for safety. What is the maost appropriate next step?
options: A. Refer him far psychotherapy for post-traumatic stress disorder
B. Reassure him that this is normal bereavement

question: A 59-year-old man well known ta his primary care physician presents complaining of excessive fatigue during the daytime. He is accompanied by his wife, who says that he wakes frequently during the night and snores loudly. She warries because sometimes it sounds like he is gasping far breath at night. options: A. Hypertension is a frequent complication
B. Weight lass may improve symptoms

question: An anxious mather brings her 4-year-ald san to clinic for a new patient visit. She says that her son was progressing well developmentally and meeting all milestones until three manths ago. Since then, she and her husband have noticed a marked restriction in the boy's activities. He keeps to himself, refuses to play with his siblings, speaks only when spoken ta, and appears indifferent to the presence of others. Attempts to engage the child in conversation are unsuccessful. He seems disinterested and refuses to make eye contact. While in the examination room, he starts banging his head against the wall. Given this clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnasis?

A 19-year-old college student presents for a first visit because she is concerned about her "abnormal behavior" She says that she warries excessively about her door being locked and that she wakes several times throughout the night to confirm that the doar is properly lacked. She finds these thoughts distressing. Although she agrees that her fears are not rational, she feels unable to stop from acting on them. A BB-year-old woman with a history of well-managed sick sinus syndrome and osteoporosis is brought to the physician by her daughter. According to the daughter, her mother has become increasingly forgetful and irritable aver the past two years. A 59-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset paralysis of her bilateral lower extremities. She has no other symptoms. Physical examination reveals normal tone, normal deep tendon reflexes, and no Babinski sign. Her maotar strength is 3/5 in bath lower extremities. The remainder of her examination is unremarkable. A mather brings in her 3-year-old son to the pediatrician because she is concerned about his "poor development." A 21-year-old college junior requests an urgent appointment with her family physician to discuss a "persanal concern." She had not realized this could have any bearing an her own situation until she encountered an article an the Internet that mentioned genetics appears to play a role in the pathogenesis of bipolar disorder. Since then, she has had disturbed sleep and has been very worried that she too will one day develop bipolar disarder. A 25-year-old married female is brought to the emergency department by her mother for excruciating right-sided abdominal pain. A 34-year-old male calls his primary care physician's office, requesting an urgent appointment to discuss a personal problem. The patient declines the affer af an appointment and hangs up. Fifteen minutes later, as the physician is locking the office up, the patient arrives and insists on being seen immediately. B. "All right, we should look at your rash now. Come inside."

question: A 36-year-old known patient of yours presents for a routine annual examination. Toward the end of the visit, she glumly mentions that she intends to file for a divorce from her husband. She says that he is always in an irritable or depressed mood, and that she is "sick and tired of him spending huge sums of maney on gambling." He was recently fired fram his job as an insurance agent after he was caught forging signatures in an attempt to finance some gambling trips to Las Vegas. She has confronted him about his behavior on many occasions in the past, but he has always denied that it was a problem. Now he admits that he finds it hard to control himself and that he is in debt to several creditors. A 19-year-old known patient with bipolar disorder presents to her psychiatrist for a follow-up visit. Her mather is apprehensive, however, about the prospect and asks the psychiatrist to continue the medication for a longer period. D. Continue lithium for her lifetime

question: A 31-year-old woman voices her anger at the increasing number of immigrants who compete for job apportunities in her chosen field of computer science. She observes that many of her friends in the local community are alsa experiencing difficulty in securing appealing employment because af the influx of immigrants. This waman volunteers in her spare time to provide vocational guidance to new immigrant families in the community. Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is she demonstrating?

A 25-year-old Caucasian woman presents as a new patient after having recently moved to the neighborhood. She says that she was diagnosed with anorexia nervosa two years ago, and that her disorder resolved after intensive psychotherapy. Although her eating pattern is normal now, she is still underweight. Her menstrual cycles have been regular far the past year. She recently married and is now interested in starting a family with her husband. She asks whether her history of anorexia nervosa will affect her ability to conceive ar carry a healthy child to term. Given this clinical presentation, which of the following complications is most likely?
options: C. Small for gestational age baby

question: A fourth-year medical student develops a new anset headache that he describes as "excruciating." He denies any fever or vomiting. He requests the emergency department physician to order a CT scan of his head, as he is certain that he has developed an intracranial hemorrhage. A complete warkup, including an ophthalmologic evaluation, is negative. options: A Initiate a discussion about current emotional stressors

question: A 57-year-old Caucasian woman presents for a follow-up visit regarding her lower back pain. She originally presented with this complaint last month and was advised to limit activity and use ibuprofen as needed. When her pain persisted, she was scheduled far an MRI of her back. B. "You should have come earlier for a medical checkup. It is now too late."
C. "We will try our best. However, once a tumor metastasizes, the prognosis is poor.”

question: A 44-year-old woman presents for a follow-up visit regarding her severe depression. She has taken numerous antidepressants over the years with little symptomatic relief, and cantinues to spend the majarity of her time in seclusion, experiencing intense feelings of worthlessness and despair. Her hushand is deeply concerned about the impact her depression has had on their marriage and their two teenage children. He requests information about "all available options” to improve his wife's symptoms. The prospect of electraconvulsive therapy (ECT) is discussed, and the husband inquires about potential drawbacks to the procedure. An anxious mather brings in her 12-year-old daughter to your clinic for "severe hair loss". On examination, you find several alopecic patches on her head. While taking a detailed history, you find out that the young girl has been pulling aut her hair when stressed. Although she has been indulging in this behaviar periodically since childhood, she finds a recent increase in the same. She reveals to you that she is "really nervous" about her upcoming exams, and has disturbed sleep. She also adds that she feels so stressed that she has been avoiding going out with her friends and keeps to her books all the time. She denies any alterations in weight, but does admit to a decreased appetite. What do you think is the underlying diagnosis in this case?

A 42-year-old Caucasian man presents to the emergency department complaining of a two-day histary of fever to 40C (104F), headache, and vomiting. Physical examination reveals petechiae and purpura an his trunk and lower extremities. Examination of his cerebraspinal fluid is cansistent with bacterial meningitis. The patient is told of his diagnosis and the need for antibiotics and hospitalization is discussed. The patient refuses to be admitted to the hospital, however, and insists upon being treated at home. What is the most appropriate next step?
options: A. Treat the patient against his wishes
B. Discuss the situation with the patient's wife and ask that she convince him to accept hospitalization
C. Consult with the hospital ethics committee
D. Respect the patient's decision and arrange for home antibiotic therapy

question: A 17-year-old girl is brought to clinic by her mother because of recent weight loss. The mother relates that her daughter has lost 10 Ibs (4 5 ka) in the last two months The mother says that her daughter has suddenly become a "picky eater” since starting college and that she often refuses to eat now, insisting that she is "not hungry " Friends of the girl have confided that she is behaving strangely at schoal. When questioned about these concerns, the girl denies having any problems and says that she feels just fine. Her height is 5'2" {157.5 cm) and her weight is 100 lbs (45 kg). Physical examination reveals erythema of her turbinates and nasal septum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

You are the physician covering for a colleague wha is out of town when a young man brings in his mother, a G5-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and ischemic heart disease. She is complaining of markedly decreased urine output for the past twelve hours. Two days ago, your colleague performed a coronary angiography on her. Her vital signs today include temperature of 37.0C (98.6F), blood pressure of 140/92 mm Hg, pulse of 88/min, and respirations of 14/min. Labaratory results include creatinine of 2.4 mg/dL and BUN of 30 mg/dL. You suspect acute tubular necrosis secondary to the contrast used during angiography. After reviewing the nates in her medical chart befare and after the procedure, you realize that this complication could have been prevented with adequate hydration prior to the angiogram. The patient's son appears very concerned, and he asks what is responsible for his mother's inability to urinate. What is the most appropriate next step?
options: A Initiate appropriate therapy for acute tubular necrosis but refrain from divulging information to the patient or her son about the cause of her condition
B. State that this complication is seen frequently in patients who undergo angiograms
C. State that the cause of her condition is unknown, but that she will be given excellent treatment

D. State that her condition appears to be related to her recent angiogram, but that the matter will have to be discussed with your colleague when he returns before a definitive answer can be established

question: A 21-year-old woman presents to the physician at her mother's urging because she has been experiencing significant sleep disturbances. Three months aga, she was the victim of a sexual assault in the parking lat of her workplace. Since then, she has had recurrent nightmares about the assault, and dreads falling asleep at night. During the day, she has flashbacks about the assault. She has become very withdrawn, quit her job, and avoids other people. The woman is very distressed about the flashbacks and says that they "dominate her life." She has difficulty concentrating and startles easily when others speak to her. Which of the following is the mast likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old married woman presents with lower back pain that has persisted far the past week. She says she developed the pain after lifting some heawy furniture. She denies any other symptoms. A thorough physical examination reveals mild paraspinal muscle spasm. There is nao significant pain with a straight leg raise on either side. Multiple bruises on her abdomen, back, and chest are also evident. When the topic of the bruises is raised, the woman becomes tearful and begins to cry. options: B. "lt would seem that someane is physically abusing you."
C. "Would you like to tell me a little more about these bruises?"
D. "Physical abuse is against the law. | recommend you file a report with the police if you have been a victim of an assault."

question: A 31-year-old Caucasian female with a chronic history of schizophrenia presents for a prescription refill at her local mental health clinic. She has been treated with olanzapine far the last six months. The psychiatrist notes at this visit that the woman appears less agitated and complains af fewer auditory hallucinations. A 27-year-old female is brought to the emergency department by her husband after she fainted at home. The patient admits that she has been fasting and exercising vigorously for the past two days to compensate for the excessive amount of food she ate three days ago. She admits to a similar pattern of eating large amounts of food followed by a period of fasting since she lost her job a few months ago. Her height is 5'4" (163 cm) and weight is 120 lbs (54 kg). Physical examination is unremarkable. What is the mast likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old married nurse who works with you in clinic comes to you privately, saying that she "missed a period" this month. An over-the-counter urine pregnancy test confirms that she is pregnant. The first-trimester laboratory testing is performed, and she is found also to be HIV-positive. When you reveal the news of her HIV status to her, she is devastated. She hesitantly reveals that she had unprotected sexual intercourse with a former boyfriend several months ago. You explain that her husband's HIV status must be evaluated. Upon hearing this, the nurse is horrified and says. "Mo, | cannot tell him about this. He would never forgive me!" What is the mast appropriate next step?
options: A. Call and inform local health autharities immediately
B. Call and inform local health authorities and the nurse's husband immediately
C. Assure the nurse that her condition will be kept absolutely confidential
D. Encourage the nurse to infarm her husband

question: You are seeing a 41 year-old woman and her 19 year-old daughter in the emergency room because they think that they have been poisoned. The woman states that they have not been getting along with their landlord lately because they have been late an their last few rent payments. They say that the landlord is harassing them by banging on their floor at all hours of the night, turning down their heat, and asking the other tenants ta spy on them. Last month, the waman thinks the landlord tried to spy on them by installing video cameras in her living room while they were out. Today, she tasted something odd in her food, and is convinced that she and her daughter have been poisoned in an attempt to get them out of the apartment once and for all. She came immediately to the hospital for treatment and to collect evidence of the poisoning. The mother is very protective of her daughter, wha seems rather submissive and passive. She completely agrees with her mother's description of the events. Which of the following is the best course of action?
options: A Discharge bath the mather and the daughter after a complete physical examination and blood tests.
B. Admit the mather ta the psychiatric unit fa Tesenats ami nat the dau§HeEe
C. Admit the daughter to the psychiatric unit for treatment, but not the mather.
D. Admit the mother and the daughter to the same psychiatric unit.

question: A 25-year-old female college student comes to the office due to episodes of palpitations and sweating. The episodes are sudden in onset and usually last for 5 minutes, after which she feels very embarrassed. During an episode, she is usually overcome with fear, and her friends have noted that she becomes pale and trembles. These symptoms started approximately 2 months ago, and have been occurring more frequently. Which of the following conditions is mast commonly associated with this patient's disorder?
explanation:
This young female has panic disorder. The lifetime prevalence of this psychiatric condition is estimated as 5% in women and 2% in men. Panic attacks are characterized by the sudden onset of intense apprehension, fear or terror, and accompanied by the abrupt development of specific somatic symptoms. These most commonly include: chest pain, palpitations, headaches, dizziness, faintness, dyspnea, abdominal pain, paresthesias and trembling.
The DSM criteria state that the following must be met;
1. At least 3 attacks in a 3 week period
2. No clear circumscribed stimulus
3. Abrupt onset of symptoms which peak within 10 minutes
Problems commonly associated with panic disorder are: depression, agoraphobia, generalized anxiety, and substance abuse. Observational studies have shown that 1/3 to 1/2 of patients meet DSM-IV criteria for major depression at initial presentation, while greater than 80% have had one or more lifetime episodes of major depression. Approximately 40% of patients meet the criteria for agoraphobia.
(Choice A) Alcoholism and abuse of sedative hypnotics are occasionally associated with panic disorder, but are not as common as the association between depression and panic disorder.
(Choices B, D and E) Obsessive-compulsive disorder, somatization disorders, and bipolar disorder do not have a documented association with panic disorder.
Educational Objective:
Patients suffering from panic disorder have an increased incidence of depression, agoraphobia, generalized anxiety and substance abuse.

question: A 32-year-old man is admitted to the hospital after being found on the edge of a bridge. He appears severely depressed, stating that his life is over. He is in financial ruin, and his wife recently left him, taking his children with her. He is crying, unable ta sleep, has no appetite, and continues to express a feeling of hopelessness and suicidal thoughts. He is started on sertraline and clonazepam for his symptoms. Later in the day, the patient becomes more upset and starts to bang his head repeatedly against the edge of the sink. He is given intramuscular injections of lorazepam and haloperidol to help reduce his agitation, and is physically restrained for a brief period of time. He continues to be agitated at times during the next few days, and requires emergent lorazepam and haloperidol three mare times as well as physical restraints twice more. On the third day, the patient is notably calmer, but is unable to get out of bed. He appears confused and does not respond to questions appropriately. He is diaphoretic and has a temperature of 103.1 F (39.5 C). His blood pressure is 167/97 mmHg and his pulse is 112/min. As the staff attempts to get him out of bed, they notice that his arms are stiff and difficult to bend. Which of the following is the mast likely cause for his symptoms?
explanation:
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is associated with medications that block dopamine transmission, and is characterized by the following clinical features: fever, rigidity, mental status changes, and autonomic instability. NMS is a rare, potentially life-threatening complication of treatment with antipsychotics, and is more commonly associated with the use of high-potency, typical antipsychotics like haloperidol. Treatment includes discontinuation of all antipsychotics, aggressive monitoring in the ICU, control of hyperthermia, and maintenance of electrolyte balance. Dantrolene is a skeletal muscle relaxant that may be used to relieve symptoms in severe cases. Mortality from NMS is high, approaching 10-20%.
This patient has fever, mental status changes, and rigidity, which are most likely the result of repeated doses of haloperidol.
(Choice A) This patient's head banging may result in an intracranial bleed with subsequent altered mental status, but this would not explain his other symptoms.
(Choice B) Patients who are physically restrained sometimes have mild elevations of creatinine phosphokinase, which is caused by muscle breakdown as a result of the physical struggle. However, fever, altered mental status, and rigidity would not result from physical restraints.
(Choice D) The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor sertraline can cause serotonin syndrome when given in combination with a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI). Serotonin syndrome can sometimes appear clinically similar to NMS, with high fevers and rigidity. However, it often begins with diarrhea, restlessness, and autonomic instability.
(Choice E) The patient's symptoms of fever, rigidity, and altered mentation are not related to worsening depression.
Educational objective:
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition that can occur after administration of antipsychotic medications. Symptoms include fever, rigidity, altered mental status, and autonomic instability.

question: A middle-aged woman brings her 15-year-old daughter to clinic because she is concerned about having heard her daughter vomit in the bathroom on two separate occasions last week. The girl is a gymnast preparing far an important regional competition. She denies having vomited, though she does admit to trying to lose weight because she is "too fat." Vital signs include temperature of 36.2C (97.1F), blood pressure of 106/68 mm Hg, pulse of 62/min, and respirations of 16/min. Physical examination reveals her height to be 5' (152.4 cm) and her weight to be 80 Ibs (36.2 kg). She is emaciated and her skin is very pale. There are abrasions on the backs of her fingers. Her parotid glands are swollen and her breath smells foul. Her menstrual history is significant for three months of amenorrhea. The family history is significant far hemophilia. The girl takes no medications and has no drug allergies. Which af the following is the mast likely diagnosis?
options: A. Eating disorder, not otherwise specified
explanation:
Anorexia nervosa is most common in adolescent girls from affluent families. The DSM-IV criteria for the diagnosis of anorexia nervosa include: 1) body weight at least 15% below normal weight, accompanied by a refusal to maintain body weight at normal levels: 2) amenorrhea for three months; 3) distortion of body image in which the individual views herself as obese, when she is in fact thin; and 4) fear of gaining weight or becoming fat despite being underweight. To continue to lose weight, individuals suffering from anorexia nervosa will either: 1) fast and/or exercise (the restricting subtype), or 2) binge eat followed by laxative usage or induced vomiting (the binge and purge subtype).
On physical examination of the anorexic patient, the most striking finding is emaciation. Some individuals also develop lanugo (a fine downy body hair) on the back and abdomen. Those anorexics who induce vomiting may have enlarged parotids, dental enamel erosion, and scars or calluses on the hand from contact with the teeth. Other common findings include bradycardia, hypotension, hypothermia, and dry skin. Electrolyte abnormalities secondary to vomiting are often discovered as well.
(Choice A) Eating disorder, not otherwise specified is the correct diagnosis in patients whose eating disorder does not meet the criteria for specific conditions (eg, a patient who meets the criteria for anorexia nervosa but has regular menses).
(Choice C) The most prominent features of bulimia nervosa include episodes of binge eating followed by feelings of disgust or guilt, repeated compensatory behavior to prevent weight gain after the binge (eg, induced vomiting, laxative abuse), and a normal or slightly above normal BMI.
(Choice D) Oppositional defiant disorder is a childhood condition characterized by defiant and hostile behavior. Symptoms are milder than those seen with conduct disorder.
(Choice E) Somatization disorder is characterized by physical symptoms or complaints that have no organic basis.
Educational Objective:
Anorexia nervosa is always associated with amenorrhea and a body weight that is below normal. Bulimia nervosa, in contrast, is associated with normal menses and body weight.

question: A 49-year-old male with a history of paranoid schizophrenia is admitted to the psychiatric ward because of an increase in his auditory hallucinations. He reports that for the past week, he has heard new voices telling him to set fire to himself. The patient has been unemployed for the past five years and he admits ta increasing his alcohol intake following a bitter divorce earlier this year. He has attempted suicide on multiple occasions in the past. His medical history is significant for poorly controlled diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Which one of the following factars is the best predictor of this patient's likelihood to commit suicide in the future?
explanation:
The strongest indicator that a future suicide attempt is likely is a history of previous suicide attempt(s).
(Choice A) Although females are more likely to make suicidal gestures, males are more likely to successfully commit suicide. Therefore, male gender is considered to be a risk factor for suicide.
(Choices B, C and E) Alcohol or substance abuse, Unemployment and Recent divorce are risk factors for suicide, but are less significant than a history of previous suicide attempts.
(Choice F) Individuals age 45 years or older are at increased risk for committing suicide. Elderly single males are at particularly heightened risk. However, age is less significant than a history of previous suicide attempts.
Educational Objective:
The greatest risk factor for committing suicide is a past history of suicide attempt(s).

question: A 28-year-old woman presents complaining of "paralyzing anxiety" that developed five months aga shartly after she was in a minor car accident that caused no physical injury or property damage. This anxiety has induced her ta quit her job of three years as a computer technician because she dreaded driving ta wark each day. She no longer enjoys going on road trips or scenic drives like she ance did and now experiences extreme nervousness just at the thought of having ta drive. She has also started drinking several glasses of wine each night and avoids all social situations. She reports difficulty in falling asleep. She denies any personal or family history of psychiatric illness. Given her presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional or behavioral symptoms that develop within three months of exposure to an identifiable stressor and that rarely last more than six months after the stressor has ended. The patient experiences marked distress in excess of what would be expected from exposure to the stressor. In this scenario, the woman's anxiety arising from the minor car accident is far greater than would be expected, as evidenced by her quitting her job, drinking to excess, and avoiding social situations. Therefore, the diagnosis of adjustment disorder is appropriate.
(Choice A) Adjustment disorder is often difficult to differentiate from major depression because of an overlap in symptoms. Although this patient meets the depression criteria for symptom duration (two weeks or more), she does not have five or more symptoms of major depression.
(Choice B) Patients suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) persistently re-experience the traumatic event in the form of recurrent nightmares and flashbacks. Places, people, or activities that are reminders of the trauma are avoided. Anhedonia, social detachment, and hypervigilance are common, and difficulties with sleep and concentration may arise. Symptoms must be present for longer than one month.
(Choice C) Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive, uncontrollable worry about various different events and activities. Occurring most every day for at least six months, symptoms include three or more of the following: restlessness easy fatigue irritability, poor concentration, and sleep disturbance.
(Choice D) Acute stress disorder presents with the same symptoms observed in PTSD, but the symptoms are present for less than four weeks.
Educational Objective:
Adjustment disorder results in marked distress in excess of what is expected from exposure to the triggering stressor.

question: A friend from childhood calls your office because he is distressed by his girlfriend's behavior. He was deeply embarrassed this past weekend when his girlfriend was caught stealing a pair of gloves from an acquaintance at a party he attended with her. He also reveals that she frequently steals items of minimal value fram stores. Because of this behavior, she has a criminal record. He adds that when he confronts her about her behavior, she admits that she gets "a kick out of stealing” but that she feels some remorse later. Which of the following is this woman mast likely suffering from?
explanation:
Kleptomania is a rare disorder characterized by an inability to resist the impulse to steal objects that are either of low monetary value or are not needed for personal use. Individuals suffering from kleptomania periodically develop significant tension that is alleviated by stealing. The condition is more prevalent in females and is occasionally associated with bulimia nervosa, and can have a chronic or sporadic course.
(Choice A) Borderline personality disorder is characterized by marked impulsivity and a pattern of unstable relationships. Individuals with the condition oscillate between extremes of idealization and devaluation of others. They frequently indulge in self-mutilation and may make suicidal gestures. Because there is no indication that these features are present in the woman in this scenario, borderline personality disorder is an unlikely diagnosis.
(Choice B) Antisocial personality disorder is characterized by a pattern of repetitive and persistent behavior in which the basic rules of society and the rights of others are violated. Individuals with this condition are at least 18 years of age and have had conduct disorder in childhood.
(Choice C) Conduct disorder is a childhood behavioral problem that presents in a similar fashion to antisocial personality disorder. Children suffering from this disorder lie, steal, destroy property, set fires, and are cruel to animals and people.
(Choice D) Manic episodes are characterized by abnormally expansive mood, grandiosity, decreased need for sleep, flight of ideas, talkativeness, and increased involvement in pleasurable activities that have the potential for painful consequences (eg, spending exorbitant amounts of money, gambling, sexual indiscretion). The woman in this scenario derives pleasure from stealing items of little significance but does not demonstrate any of the other behaviors required to make a diagnosis of a mania.
Educational Objective:
Kleptomania is characterized by an inability to resist the impulse to steal objects that either are of low monetary value or are not needed for personal use. The condition is more prevalent in females and is occasionally associated with bulimia nervosa.

question: A 19-year-old man brings his 17-year-old girlfriend ta the emergency department because she is complaining of nausea, vomiting, and severe pain in the lower right quadrant of her abdomen. She is also febrile and anorexic. Her symptams have been present far almast twelve hours. Physical examination and computed tomography scan of the abdomen are suggestive of acute appendicitis, and the need for an appendectomy is discussed with the patient and her boyfriend. Who should sign the consent form for the procedure?
explanation:
This patient is a minor and therefore cannot consent to her own medical or surgical treatment. The physician will need to contact the girl's parent or legal guardian to obtain consent before proceeding.
(Choice B) Although the boyfriend is an adult, he does not have the legal authority to provide consent for a medical procedure to be performed on his girlfriend.
(Choice C) Because the girl is a minor, she does not have the authority to consent to medical treatment unless it is regarding a protected issue (eg, contraception, pregnancy, drug abuse).
(Choices D and E) Physicians and other unrelated adult authority figures (eg, coaches or teachers) do not have the legal authority to provide consent for this girl.
Educational Objective:
Minors normally cannot consent to their own medical treatment. Parents or legal guardians must provide consent on the girl's behalf before the physician can proceed, although exceptions are made for emergent situations.

question: A 45-year-old Caucasian man is fired from his job as a mechanical engineer. He had been warking for the same company far twenty years and was completely unprepared for this turn of events. When he arrives home, he is in a foul mood. His wife questions him about his demeanor and he snaps at her, cursing her for an unkempt house. Which of the following defense mechanisms is this man using?
explanation:
Defense mechanisms are an unconscious attempt to reduce anxiety and adjust to a stressful situation. To minimize anxiety, the ego learns to distort internal reality or the perception of external reality. Defense mechanisms can be destructive if overused or if used at the wrong time.
In this scenario, the engineer is upset about being fired from his job of twenty years. He reacts to the situation by turning his anger on his wife when he comes home. He has thus displaced his negative emotions onto his wife, who he considers a "safer" target than his employer.
(Choice A) An immature defense mechanism, acting out is the expression of an unconscious impulse through a physical action. An example would be this engineer screaming and kicking the floor when he discovered he was fired.
(Choice C) A neurotic defense mechanism, dissociation involves blocking off disturbing thoughts or feelings from consciousness in an attempt to avoid emotional upset. An example would be this engineer blocking out the fact that he was fired, with his wife discovering the truth only when a concerned friend calls from work to give her condolences.
(Choice D) A neurotic defense mechanism, rationalization is the offering of a rational, logical reason for an upsetting event rather than the real reason. An example would be this engineer stating that being fired was a "blessing in disguise," as he can now spend more time with his family.
(Choice E) Conversion is a defense mechanism in which emotional conflicts are transformed into physical (often neurological) symptoms. An example would be this engineer being struck mute after learning the news of his firing.
Educational Objective:
Displacement is an immature defense mechanism in which the individual displaces negative feelings associated with an unacceptable object or situation onto a "safer" object or situation.

question: A 27-year-old Caucasian male is brought to the emergency department by police officers. The man was found naked at a traffic signal, cursing at drivers and assaulting nearby pedestrians. He has a long history of palysubstance abuse and has been admitted several times to the hospital with a similar presentation each time. Attempts to elicit history from the patient prove unsuccessful, as he is highly agitated and combative. He keeps repeating, "They are all out to get me. They are coming through the walls, ready to kill me!" Vital signs include temperature of 36.5C (97.8F), blood pressure of 148/100 mm Hg, pulse of 84/min, and respirations of 16/min. Physical examination reveals ataxia, nystagmus, and muscle rigidity. This patient's presentation is mast consistent with intoxication with which of the following drugs?
explanation:
Patients with PCP intoxication usually present with distinct behavioral changes such as physical aggression, severe agitation, impulsivity, impaired judgment, psychosis, paranoia, or hallucinations. These symptoms develop shortly after ingestion of the drug. Physical signs such as nystagmus, hypertension, tachycardia, ataxia, dysarthria, muscle rigidity, seizures, or coma may also be evident.
(Choice A) Alcohol intoxication can also present with ataxia, nystagmus, aggression, and impaired judgment. However, hallucinations are more commonly a feature of alcohol withdrawal, not alcohol intoxication.
(Choice B) Heroin intoxication would present with pinpoint pupils, drowsiness, CNS depression, and constipation.
(Choice C) LSD is a hallucinogen. Shortly after ingesting this drug, individuals may experience mood impairment, hallucinations, subjective perceptual intensification (ie, colors are richer, tastes are heightened, and sensation is enhanced), depersonalization, and illusions. In addition, two or more of the following signs are often present: sweating, tachycardia, pupillary dilatation, palpitations, tremors, and poor coordination.
(Choice E) Cocaine intoxication presents with anxiety, aggression, agitation, psychosis, or delirium. Physical findings may include high or low blood pressure, tachycardia or bradycardia, sweating, pupillary dilatation, nausea or vomiting, or insomnia. Overdoses can cause cardiac arrhythmias, myocardial infarctions, seizures, or stroke. Infrequently, patients present with formication (also known as "cocaine bugs"), in which the individual is convinced there are bugs crawling all over him. Nosebleeds and septal perforation can occur in patients who snort cocaine.
Educational Objective:
PCP and LSD intoxication present similarly, but agitation and aggression occur more often in patients using PCP. Visual hallucinations and intensified perceptions are hallmarks of LSD use.

question: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found in the park talking to himself. When authorities asked him ta leave, he became agitated and combative, saying he was "destined to lead" and has to "wait in the park for the sign." After calming down a little during the evaluation, he admits ta not sleeping for the past week. His thoughts jump from topic to topic, and he is highly distractible. The patient is admitted to the hospital and started on daily haloperidal and carbamazepine. Over the next week, he becomes significantly calmer. Although he continues to have beliefs that he will "lead a spiritual revolution” he is sleeping six hours a night and is better able to focus. Ten days after admission, he fails to come out of his room for breakfast. The nursing staff find him lying in bed, confused, sweating, and stiff. Vital signs are temperature 39.2°C (102.6°F), blood pressure 164/98 mmHg, pulse 122/min, and respiratory rate 28/min. Which of the following medications would be most appropriate to administer at this time?
explanation:
This patient has neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS). NMS is a relatively uncommon but potentially lethal side effect caused by antipsychotic (neuroleptic) medications, in this case haloperidol. It may occur at any time during treatment with dopamine antagonists. The cardinal features of NMS include hyperthermia, autonomic instability, muscular rigidity, and altered sensorium. Laboratory evaluation reveals elevated CPK levels. Rhabdomyolysis, followed by myoglobinuria that can cause acute renal failure, is a known complication. Treatment of NMS includes prompt discontinuation of the responsible neuroleptic agent followed by supportive care (i.e. aggressive cooling, antipyretics, fluid and electrolyte repletion, and alkaline diuresis in the case of rhabdomyolysis). Specific pharmacologic therapies include dantrolene sodium (which is a direct muscle relaxant), amantadine, and/or the dopamine agonist bromocriptine.
(Choice A) The anticholinergic medication benztropine can be used to treat antipsychotic-induced extrapyramidal symptoms, but it is not used in the management of NMS.
(Choice C) Naloxone is used to treat opioid overdose, but has no role in the treatment of NMS.
(Choice D) Physostigmine is used to reverse toxic CNS effects caused by anticholinergic drugs. It is not used in the treatment of NMS.
(Choice E) The beta-blocker propranolol can be used to control the hypertension and tachycardia associated with NMS, but it would not address the cause of these isolated symptoms. Propranolol is sometimes used to treat the antipsychotic side effect akathisia.
Educational objective:
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is an unusual but potentially lethal side effect from the use of antipsychotics (neuroleptics). It is treated primarily with dantrolene sodium and supportive care.

question: A middle-aged, divorced woman brings her 17-year-old daughter ta the physician with the complaint that her daughter "seems abnormal ". She is concerned because her daughter has no close friends and does not date. The mather adds that she has to be particularly careful of comments she makes because her daughter is especially sensitive to criticism. Otherwise, the mother reports, her daughter is very polite, well behaved, and earns excellent grades in high school. When questioned about her behavior, the daughter breaks down in tears and says, "The reality is no one wants to be friends with someone ugly and stupid like me." Which of the following personality disorders is demonstrated by the girl's behavior?
explanation:
This patient is socially isolated, hypersensitive to criticism, and lacks self-esteem. Her tearful reply to the physician's inquiry suggests that she is unhappy with her situation and would like to make friends but fears being humiliated or rejected. Her presentation is therefore suggestive of avoidant personality disorder, a condition in which individuals consider themselves inferior to others and avoid participating in new activities or taking risks for fear of being embarrassed.
(Choice A) Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by social detachment and a restricted range of expressed emotion. These patients do not enjoy close relationships with others and prefer to be aloof and isolated. They rarely indulge in any pleasurable activities and appear indifferent to praise or criticism. They are able to recognize reality, however, and do not demonstrate the bizarre cognition or psychosis that would be consistent with schizophrenia.
(Choice B) Individuals with dependent personality disorder have an excessive need to be cared for and tend to be clingy and submissive with loved ones. They are usually indecisive and avoid taking the initiative because of feelings of inadequacy. They have difficulty expressing disagreement with others for fear of losing support, and they dread being left alone to fend for themselves.
(Choice C) Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by eccentric behavior and a reduced capacity for close relationships. These patients usually exhibit "magical thinking" that is inconsistent with cultural norms. They may have bizarre fantasies or believe in telepathy, clairvoyance, or the concept of a sixth sense.
(Choice E) Individuals with borderline personality disorder show a pattern of instability in relationships and marked impulsivity. They swing wildly between scorning and idealizing people (with others considered wholly good or wholly bad, a phenomenon known as "splitting"). They tend to be impulsive and reckless and may demonstrate suicidal or self-mutilating behavior. Feelings of anger and chronic emptiness are common.
Educational Objective:
Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by shyness, feelings of inferiority, and a desire to make friends that is overridden by an intense fear of embarrassment or rejection.

question: A 22-year-old male presents for a psychiatric evaluation after assaulting his girlfriend during a domestic dispute. This is the third time he has been arrested for violence towards his girlfriend. He admits to the violent behavior, but blames his girlfriend by stating that she nags him tao much about getting a job. He states, "l could get a job if | wanted to, but why should I?" The man has also been arrested several times for larceny and drug possession. He did not complete high schoal because he was suspended for repeated truancy and fighting with peers. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Antisocial personality disorder is characterized by a pattern of disregard for and violation of the rights of others, which typically begins by middle adolescence and continues into adulthood. Individuals with antisocial personality disorder routinely engage in illegal activities (e.g. drug use, assault, or theft), endanger the well-being of others, and frequently lie. They tend to be aggressive and impulsive, and have difficulty maintaining employment. Despite these features, however, affected individuals frequently display a superficial charm that allows for the manipulation of others.
(Choice B) Individuals with borderline personality disorder often show a pattern of instability in relationships and can be impulsive and/or reckless. However, they also have identity disturbance, recurrent suicidal or self-mutilating behavior, and feelings of emptiness, none of which this patient has. Therefore, antisocial personality disorder is a much more appropriate diagnosis.
(Choice C) Children and adolescents with conduct disorder often became adults with antisocial personality disorder. The diagnosis of conduct disorder requires at least three symptoms from the following categories: aggression towards people or animals, destruction of property, deceitfulness or theft, or a serious violation of rules. However, if someone qualifies for the diagnosis of antisocial personality disorder, they no longer have conduct disorder.
(Choice D) Individuals with histrionic personality disorder demonstrate excessively labile emotions and attention-seeking behavior, which is not observed in this patient.
(Choice E) Individuals with narcissistic personality disorder often have an exaggerated sense of self importance, demonstrate arrogant behavior, and lack empathy for others. However, they usually do not break the law and are not violent towards others.
Educational objective:
Antisocial personality disorder is diagnosed in patients aged 18 years or older who engage in illegal activities (e.g. theft or assault) and disregard the rights of others. These individuals often display evidence of conduct disorder as minors.

question: A 43-year-old male with a long history of schizophrenia is hospitalized for recurrent auditory hallucinations and delusions. He says that he hears voices coming from his radio warning about the "secret government agents" that hunt far him. He is certain that his next-door neighbor is spying on him and listening through the wall on behalf of the government. His sister tells the attending physician that the patient lives by himself and has been treated with risperidone for several years. Because of repeated episodes of noncompliance with his medication, he has experienced multiple relapses that required hospitalization. He was most recently discharged from the hospital twa months ago. Which of these would be the antipsychotic of choice for the long-term treatment of this patient?
explanation:
Treatment noncompliance in schizophrenic patients is common and results from several factors. Patients who live by themselves, who have poor social support systems, who are elderly, or who have developed side effects with the use of neuroleptics are all more likely to be noncompliant with their medications. This noncompliance leads to symptom exacerbation, relapse, and recurrent hospitalization. It is therefore recommended that schizophrenic patients with a history of noncompliance be given long-acting injectable antipsychotics such as fluphenazine or haloperidol. When administered in an outpatient setting at regularly scheduled intervals (usually twice per month), high doses of injectable antipsychotics allow for better symptom control and circumvent the issue of poor medication adherence.
(Choices A, C, and E) These antipsychotics are taken orally and would therefore most likely result in a continuing pattern of noncompliance. It would be preferable to periodically administer an injectable antipsychotic on an outpatient basis instead.
Educational Objective:
Depot antipsychotics such as fluphenazine and haloperidol are the treatment of choice for schizophrenic patients who suffer relapses due to treatment noncompliance.

question: A 37-year-old male patient with a history of bipolar affective disarder with psychasis is accompanied ta clinic by his wife. He is a known patient and has been treated for the past three years with lithium and risperidone. His wife states that her husband's symptoms are remarkably well managed with the medications, but she is concerned about some new, abnormal movements that he has recently begun to make. While being physically examined, the man repeatedly protrudes his tongue and smacks his lips. There are also some abnormal rolling movements of his fingers. Which of the following is the patient most likely experiencing?
explanation:
Antipsychotics are classified as typical and atypical. Extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) occur frequently as side effects of typical antipsychotics but may also occasionally occur with the use of atypical antipsychotics. This patient has developed tardive dyskinesia as a side effect of risperidone usage. Tardive dyskinesia is characterized by involuntary perioral movements such as biting, chewing, grimacing, and tongue protrusions. Involuntary choreoathetoid movements of the head, limbs, and trunk may also be observed. The condition usually arises after four months and before four years of treatment, and may be irreversible. Risperidone is the atypical antipsychotic most likely to cause EPS, while clozapine is the atypical antipsychotic least likely to cause EPS. Therefore, tardive dyskinesia is best managed by immediately discontinuing the offending antipsychotic and replacing it with clozapine. Because clozapine is associated with agranulocytosis, it is typically considered to be a medication of last resort.
(Choice A) Akathisia is a subjective feeling of restlessness that compels patients to constantly move around. It can occur at any time during treatment with antipsychotics. Beta-blockers provide some relief.
(Choice C) Dystonia can occur at any time between four hours and four days after receiving an antipsychotic medication. The condition is characterized by muscle spasms or stiffness, tongue protrusion or twisting, opisthotonus, and oculogyric crisis. Antihistamines such as diphenhydramine or anticholinergics such as benztropine provide relief.
(Choice D) Parkinsonism can also occur, developing between four days and four months after receiving an antipsychotic medication. It presents with cogwheel rigidity, masked facies, bradykinesis, pill-rolling finger tremors, and shuffling gait. Treatment is with anticholinergics such as benztropine.
(Choice E) Although lithium can cause tremors, it does not cause involuntary perioral movements. It is therefore an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.
Educational Objective:
The extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) frequently seen with typical antipsychotics include dystonia, Parkinsonism, tardive dyskinesia, akathisia, and neuroleptic malignant syndrome. The atypical antipsychotic medication most likely to cause EPS is risperidone. Tardive dyskinesia is characterized by involuntary perioral movements such as biting, chewing, grimacing, and tongue protrusions.

question: Yau are the psychiatric resident on call when a 22-year-old female presents to the emergency department after attempting suicide by slashing both of her wrists. She has had multiple admissions in the past for prior suicide attempts. She admits to being extremely upset since separating recently fram her husband. She very much wanted this marriage to succeed as she has already been divorced once before. The nursing report nates that the patient has been very disruptive since admission. When you enter the patient's room, you find her surprisingly calm and pleasant. After you obtain her history and perform a physical examination, the patient warmly says that she is very happy you are her doctor. She says that the last resident wha managed her care an a previous admission was "Incompetent, rude, and loathsome " As you are leaving the room, the patient exclaims, "You are the best doctor | have ever had!" Which af the following is the mast likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Borderline personality disorder is classified as Cluster B (dramatic, emotional) and is characterized by a pattern of unstable interpersonal relationships and marked impulsivity. Patients with this condition swing wildly between devaluing and idealizing others, labeling people as wholly good or wholly bad--a phenomenon popularly known as "splitting." Borderline patients frequently demonstrate suicidal or self-mutilating behavior. Their moods tend to be unpredictable, and they have difficulty controlling anger. Chronic feelings of emptiness are common.
(Choice A) Antisocial personality disorder is classified as Cluster B (dramatic, emotional) and is characterized by a pattern of disregard for and violation of the rights of others. People with this disorder repeatedly lie and engage in unlawful activities. They tend to be aggressive and impulsive and may find it difficult to maintain employment for long. Patients must be 18 years or older to be diagnosed with the condition, and typically have a history of conduct disorder in adolescence.
(Choice B) Histrionic personality disorder is classified as Cluster B (dramatic, emotional) and is characterized by a pattern of excessive emotionality and attention seeking. These patients often use their physical appearance to draw the attention of others and may behave in a sexually provocative manner. They tend to exaggerate and dramatize their emotions, which otherwise lack depth.
(Choice C) Paranoid personality disorder is classified as Cluster A (odd, eccentric) and is characterized by a pattern of distrust and suspiciousness of others. Patients with this disorder tend to negatively interpret the actions, words, and intentions of others. They suspect that others intend to harm or deceive them, though there may be little supporting evidence for such concerns. They hold grudges for long periods and are reluctant to confide in others.
(Choice D) Dependent personality disorder is classified as Cluster C (anxious, fearful) and is characterized by clingy and submissive behavior. These patients fear separation and tend to be indecisive and unable to take the initiative. They are often preoccupied with the thought of being left to fend for themselves, and want others to assume responsibility for all major decision making. They have difficulty expressing disagreement because they fear abandonment.
(Choice F) Narcissistic personality disorder is classified as Cluster B (dramatic, emotional) and is characterized by arrogance, grandiosity, a need for admiration, and a tendency to exploit others. Patients with this condition often have a sense of excessive entitlement and may demand special treatment.
Educational Objective:
Borderline personality disorder is characterized by "splitting," unstable relationships, and impulsivity. Angry outbursts and suicidal gestures are common.

question: A 16-year-old high school junior presents for an appointment with her primary care physician, who has cared far the girl and her family for many years. The girl is normally accompanied by her mother, but today she has come alone. She looks very anxious. When asked what is wrong, she says that she and her boyfriend had unprotected sexual intercourse last night at a friend's house. She tearfully requests if there is some sart of contraception available after the fact, and adds, "Doctor, | don't want to get pregnant!" The prospect of the "morning after" pill is discussed, and the girl indicates she is very interested. She begs that her parents not be told about this visit. Given the situation, what is the mast appropriate response?
options: A. Provide the girl with a contraceptive prescription and then call her mother
B. Provide the girl with a contraceptive prescription and counsel her about safe sex
C. Infarm the girl that a prescription can only be given after talking to her mather
D. Inquire as to how the girl could be so foolish as to have unprotected sex
E. Decline to provide the prescription unless the mother provides consent
explanation:
Most states allow adolescents to consult with physicians about sexually transmitted diseases, contraception, pregnancy, and mental illness without parental consent. Therefore, the girl in this scenario should be given a prescription for oral contraceptives and counseled on safe sex. Such counseling should be provided to all adolescents who present for routine visits.
Emancipated minors are those adolescents (typically ages 13 and older) who have been legally determined to be independent and therefore able to provide informed consent for any medical treatment. Criteria that may qualify an adolescent for emancipation include marriage, parenthood, serving in the armed forces, financial independence, and living alone. Although the girl in this scenario does not appear to be an emancipated minor, she is nevertheless entitled to confidentiality when discussing concerns about sex or contraception with her physician and can consent to related treatment without parental approval.
(Choice A) Calling the girl's mother would be considered a breach of confidentiality and is therefore highly inappropriate.
(Choices C and E) Because the girl's visit is regarding contraception, it is not necessary to relay information to her parents. However, the girl should be encouraged to be more open with her parents about her sexual activity and any associated concerns.
(Choice D) Criticizing the girl as "foolish" is a judgmental response that would likely hamper future communication with her. It is better to establish a trusting, open atmosphere that allows adolescents to reveal potentially embarrassing behaviors.
Educational Objective:
Adolescents seeking a physician's care for contraception, prenatal care, sexually transmitted diseases, or substance abuse may be treated without parental consent and are entitled to strict patient confidentiality.

question: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mather for a routine examination. The boy has an eight-year history of episodes in which he utters strange sounds, clears his throat, grimaces, and blinks his eyes. Recently he has also started ta jerk his head during these episodes as well. His medical histary is otherwise unremarkable and he is earning passing grades in school. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following disorders is most likely to develop in this boy?
explanation:
Occurring more frequently in males, Tourette syndrome is characterized by multiple motor and one or more vocal tics that present before the age of 18. The tics occur many times a day (frequently in bouts) nearly every day or at regular intervals for at least one year. The motor tics frequently observed include grimacing, eye blinking, nose twitching, head jerking, and shoulder shrugging. The vocal tics include barking, grunting, squeaking, coughing, and throat clearing. In a minority of cases, coprolalia may be observed. Symptoms are exacerbated by stress and tend to subside during sleep.
Frequent comorbid conditions in this patient population include attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (60 percent) and obsessive-compulsive disorder (27 percent). Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) develops within 3-8 years after the tics first appeared. It may peak in late adolescence or in early adulthood at a time when the tics are waning. Less common comorbid conditions include anxiety, depression, and impulse control disorders.
(Choices A, C, D and E) There is an increased incidence of conduct disorder, oppositional defiant disorder, and antisocial personality disorder in patients suffering from Tourette syndrome, but attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and obsessive-compulsive disorder are more common comorbid conditions.
Educational Objective:
Patients with Tourette syndrome have a significantly increased risk of developing attention deficit hyperactivity disorder or obsessive-compulsive disorder.

question: A childhood friend makes a visit to your office. The last time you saw her was at her wedding one year ago. As the conversation proceeds, you ask her casually if married life is treating her well. She suddenly bursts into tears and admits that her husband is physically abusive, but that she can't leave him because she is deeply afraid of being alone. Going back to childhood, this woman has always had her parents make decisions for her, including those regarding her education and career. She has always been very pleasant and courteous in her dealings with others, and avoids arguments or disagreements whenever possible. Which of the following personality disorders does this woman mast likely suffer from?
explanation:
In this scenario, the friend's indecisiveness, inability to disagree with others, and willingness to stay in an abusive relationship for fear of being left alone are suggestive of dependent personality disorder. Individuals with this condition tend to be clingy and submissive, and crave the protection and care of others. They avoid taking the initiative because of feelings of inadequacy.
(Choice A) Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by an inability to express emotion and social detachment. These patients do not enjoy close relationships and prefer to be aloof and isolated. They rarely indulge in any pleasurable activities and appear indifferent to praise or criticism from others.
(Choice C) Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by a pattern of odd and eccentric behavior and a reduced capacity for close relationships. These patients usually exhibit "magical thinking." They may have bizarre fantasies or believe in telepathy, clairvoyance or the concept of a sixth sense. They often have paranoid ideation and unusual perceptual experiences.
(Choice D) Individuals with narcissistic personality disorder tend to have an exaggerated sense of self-importance, behaving arrogantly and craving constant admiration. They may be preoccupied with thoughts of unlimited power and success. A lack of empathy and willingness to exploit others is commonly seen.
(Choice E) Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by hypersensitivity to criticism, social inhibition, and feelings of inadequacy. Although these individuals want friendships, they avoid (as the name suggests) such intimate relationships because they fear ridicule. They also perceive themselves as inferior to others and are reluctant to engage in new activities or to take risks for fear of being embarrassed. Although they appear shy, individuals with this condition actually want to make friends.
Educational Objective:
Indecisiveness, a fear of being alone, and clingy and submissive behavior are all suggestive of dependent personality disorder.

question: A 42-year-old Caucasian man is brought to the emergency department by police officers after he was found wandering aimlessly at the Washington Dulles International Airport. The man appears to be confused about his identity and his whereabouts. Extensive inquiry fails to reveal any helpful information, as the patient does nat remember his name, his family members, his profession, where he lives, or how he came to be at the airport. A search of his personal belongings reveals an airline ticket from Las Vegas to Washington, D.C. Physical examination is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
The man in this scenario appears to be suffering from a dissociative fugue (from the Latin word fugere, meaning "flight"). Evidence in support of this diagnosis includes his sudden and unexpected travel, his inability to remember his past, and his confusion about his personal identity. At times, patients with this condition will assume new identities altogether.
